ANSWER: Based on the diagnosis of acute cholangitis, I recommend a comprehensive treatment approach that combines urgent medical management with procedural intervention. The initial management includes hospital admission for IV broad-spectrum antibiotics (such as piperacillin-tazobactam or ceftriaxone plus metronidazole) and urgent biliary decompression via ERCP performed by gastroenterology. This approach aligns with evidence-based guidelines and addresses both infection and obstruction. Supportive care involves IV fluids, pain control, and patient education on abstinence from alcohol and recognizing warning signs of deterioration. Close monitoring of vital signs, labs, and clinical status will be essential during hospitalization, with follow-up within 48-72 hours to reassess. Communicating clearly and repeatedly, using visual aids if needed, will help accommodate the patient's tangential storytelling style. Coordination with gastroenterology and possibly social services will ensure comprehensive care. The goal is rapid resolution of infection, relief of biliary obstruction, and prevention of complications such as abscess formation or sepsis.
